Metal ions serve as indispensable regulators in fundamental biological processes, maintaining critical physiological functions including osmotic equilibrium, acid-base regulation, intracellular signaling, and biomolecular recognition. Perturbations of ionic homeostasis can disrupt cellular integrity, leading to functional impairment and ultimately programmed cell death. Capitalizing on this paradigm, emerging nanotherapeutic approaches have pioneered the strategic induction of tumor-selective ions overloading as a potent anticancer strategy. When the ions distribution is abnormal, the cell will start the ions regulation mechanism and regulate the ions transport process by means of expulsion or internal storage to restore the physiological homeostasis [ 9 in vivo [10] [11] [12] 13 14 In this comprehensive review, we aim to systematically summarize the research progress and developmental trends in antitumor therapy centered around ions overloading, with a focus on sodium, potassium, calcium, copper, zinc, iron and manganese ions. The review encompasses various facets, including: (1) the key roles of different ions in tumor growth; (2) the underlying mechanisms of ions overloading in inhibiting tumor growth; (3) anti-tumor nanomedicine centered solely on ions overloading; (4) therapeutic strategies based on nanomedicine for combining ions overloading with other innovative therapies. Eventually, future direction and challenges of ions overloading in anti-tumor nanomedicines are elaborated, and the key problems and unsolved bottlenecks in promoting the development of ions overloading nanomedicines are also discussed ( Scheme 1 Scheme 1 Schematic overview of ions overloading based on nanoparticles for tumor treatment. Scheme 1 2 Ions overloading for tumor therapy 2.1 Sodium and potassium ions 2.1.1 Mechanisms of sodium and potassium ions overloading in tumor therapy Changes in intracellular concentrations of several key ions have been reported to have different effects on many cancers [ 15 16 + 2+ 17 2+ 18 In the field of tumor therapy, sodium ions overload exhibits unique mechanisms of action and potential applications. Under normal circumstances, cells maintain the homeostasis of low intracellular sodium and high extracellular sodium through sodium-potassium ATPase and ions channels. When sodium ions overloading occurs, it can affect tumor cells through multiple pathways. On one hand, excessive sodium ions disrupt the osmotic balance of cells, causing cells to swell due to massive water absorption and even rupture and die. Zhong et al. found that the small molecule compound Necrocide 1 (NC1) can specifically bind to and continuously activate the transient receptor potential cation channel subfamily M member 4 (TRPM4). As a non-selective monovalent cation channel, TRPM4, when activated, promotes a large influx of sodium ions, leading to membrane depolarization and subsequent induction of cell necrosis, a process named NECSO (Necrosis by Sodium Overload) [ 19 Potassium channels selectively promote potassium ions permeability between intracellular and extracellular compartments, and are extensively involved in the vital activities of cells. For instance, the expression of channels like Kv10.1 can influence the progression of the cell cycle, thereby directly increasing the proliferation of tumor cells [ 20 21 22 2.1.2 Nanoparticles for sodium ions overloading therapy Sodium ions are important ions to maintain the osmotic pressure of the fluid in the cell, and they can resist the outflow of chloride ions, thereby preventing the cell from dehydration and expansion. Controlling the flow of sodium ions can effectively affect the movement of the cell membrane, increase the impact resistance of the cell membrane, thereby promoting cell vitality and enhancing cell function. Based on these functions of sodium ions, breaking the equilibrium homeostasis of sodium ions changes the osmotic pressure of cells, which can cause cell damage. However, imbalances in its concentration can trigger cytotoxicity [ 96 97 Normal cells maintain intracellular copper homeostasis through a series of regulatory processes, wherein copper uptake is controlled by membrane transporters, subcellular distribution is achieved via copper chaperones, and copper efflux is mediated by Cu-ATPases (ATP7A/B). In contrast, tumor cells exhibit elevated copper demand due to rapid proliferation, leading to upregulated expression of copper transporters such as CTR1. Additionally, characteristics of the TME including an acidic environment and high GSH levels, provide targets for the targeted induction of copper ions overloading. Two primary strategies are employed to induce copper ions overloading including active delivery of copper ions, and inhibition of copper efflux coupled with depletion of copper chelators. Notably, copper ions overloading kills tumor cells not through traditional oxidative stress, but via a cascade of “proteotoxic stress-mitochondrial dysfunction” known as cuproptosis, which specifically targets proteins associated with the mitochondrial TCA cycle. The key molecular steps of cuproptosis are as follows [ 98 + + 99 2+ + + 10 + 9 In recent years, there has been an upsurge of interest in developing strategies to utilize copper-based nanoparticles for the treatment of tumors, while copper chelators and copper ions carriers have shown great potential in targeted cancer therapy. In contrast to copper chelators, copper ions carriers are able to increase the concentration of copper ions in tumor cells, thereby triggering excess ROS-mediated cell death [ 97 2.3.2 Nanoparticles for copper ions overloading therapy 2.3.2.1 Nanoparticles exclusively for copper ions overloading Cuproptosis, a novel form of regulated cell death, hinges on copper ionophores to mediate copper delivery into cancer cells. To date, diverse ionophores have been developed, including disulfiram, 8-hydroxyquinoline, pyrithione, and elesclomol (ES). Therefore, continuous exploration of the specific metabolic processes in different tumor types is imperative, along with the ongoing optimization of copper ions drugs. 2.4 Zinc ions 2.4.1 Mechanisms of zinc ions overloading in tumor therapy Zinc, an essential trace element in the human body, maintains intracellular homeostasis through the coordinated regulation of zinc transporter families and metallothioneins. Zinc ions overloading refers to a state where the level of intracellular free zinc ions exceeds the physiological threshold, disrupting the dynamic balance [ 113 114 2+ 2+ + 115 Zinc ions overloading exerts antitumor effects through a multi-dimensional mechanism. Its targeting relies on the high expression of zinc transporters (e.g., ZIP4, ZIP6) and low metallothioneins buffering capacity in tumor cells. This strategy provides a novel approach with both specificity and low toxicity for combined tumor therapies, holding significant potential for clinical translation. 2.4.2 Nanoparticles for zinc ions overloading therapy 2.4.2.1 Zinc MOF-induced zinc ions overloading ZIF-8, or zinc imidazolate metal-organic framework, serves dual roles as a drug carrier and a nanoreactor. Consequently, we can impede the proliferation of tumor cells by intentionally inducing ions overloading in these cells, leading to an imbalance in ions homeostasis. Through meticulous design, nanoparticles can specifically target tumor cells and release drugs in response to specific environmental stimuli. This targeted approach not only enhances treatment efficacy but also serves to prevent resistance to other treatments. Various ions induce cancer cell death through distinct mechanisms. Although various nanoplatforms based on ions overloading regulation have made great progress in the research of tumor therapy, there are still areas that need to be explored. The characteristic of calcium overloading is the excessive accumulation of intracellular Ca 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ Similar to Ca 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ 2+ Cuproptosis is a cell death mode directly induced by copper ions overloading, characterized by protein lipoylation and proteotoxic stress. In contrast, ferroptosis is primarily driven by iron-dependent lipid peroxidation and ROS accumulation, where iron ions act as critical cofactors. Nevertheless, metal ions overloading can potentiate ferroptosis by enhancing the availability of labile iron pools, thereby accelerating lipid peroxidation cascades. Cuproptosis is still in the exploratory stage, requiring continuous development of effective biomarkers to explore its relationship with cancer. Due to the potential cytotoxicity of excess copper ions, efforts are needed to enhance the controllability and targeting of copper ions release for improved biological safety. In addition, harnessing the bioimaging capabilities of manganese ions overloading nanoparticles, alongside actively exploring combined treatment strategies involving these nanoparticles and other therapeutic modalities (such as chemotherapy, immunotherapy, etc.), holds promise for overcoming tumor drug resistance and enhancing therapeutic efficacy. Furthermore, the sensitivity of tumor tissues to ions overloading depends on the metabolic state of cells, and there are differences in ions metabolism among different cell types. Targeted regulation for different cell types and the establishment of accurate biomarkers for predicting ions signals are essential. Despite the promising potential of metal ions overloading strategies in tumor therapy, their clinical translation faces multiple challenges and risks that require systematic consideration. The primary concern is the non-specific accumulation of metal ions in normal tissues, which may trigger toxic side effects, while nanocarriers used for ions delivery may trigger immune responses that further limit their biocompatibility. The complex TME, such as dense extracellular matrix and abnormal vasculature, hinders the accumulation and deep penetration of metal ions carriers in tumors, and even with ligand-modified targeted nanocarriers, the binding site barrier effect may prevent sufficient ions delivery to inner tumor cells, reducing therapeutic efficacy and increasing the risk of drug resistance. Precise regulation of intracellular metal ions concentrations is critical, as insufficient release fails to induce overload-mediated tumor cell death while excessive release exacerbates systemic toxicity, and current stimuli-responsive release systems often suffer from inconsistent responsiveness in heterogeneous TMEs, leading to uneven ions distribution within tumors that may result in incomplete tumor regression and recurrence. Therefore, based on the above discussion, further research is needed to design nanoparticles that can further improve their performance, improve the high selectivity of nanoparticles and minimize the adverse reactions caused by cancer treatment. In addition, the synergies between different ions and the synergistic effects of ions overloading with other treatments should be considered to jointly defeat tumor cells and achieve the optimal therapeutic effect.
